column2: The morrow brought a very sober-looking morning, the sun making only a few efforts to appear, and Catherine augured from it everything most favourable to her wishes.
column3: The morrow brought a very sober looking morning, the sun making only a few efforts to appear, and Catherine augured from it everything most favourable to her wishes.

column2: She applied to Mr. Allen for confirmation of her hopes, but Mr. Allen, not having his own skies and barometer about him, declined giving any absolute promise of sunshine. She applied to Mrs. Allen, and Mrs. Allen's opinion was more positive. "She had no doubt in the world of its being a very fine day, if the clouds would only go off, and the sun keep out."
column3: She applied to mr Allen for confirmation of her hopes, but mr Allen, not having his own skies and barometer about him, declined giving any absolute promise of sunshine. She applied to mrs Allen, and mrs Allen's opinion was more positive. "She had no doubt in the world of its being a very fine day, if the clouds would only go off, and the sun keep out."

column2: dear, I do believe it will be wet," broke from her in a most desponding tone.
column3: dear, I do believe it will be wet," broke from her in a most desponding tone.

column2: No walk for me today, sighed Catherine; "but perhaps it may come to nothing, or it may hold up before twelve."
column3: No walk for me today, sighed Catherine; "but perhaps it may come to nothing, or it may hold up before twelve."

column2: Perhaps it may, but then, my dear, it will be so dirty.
column3: Perhaps it may, but then, my dear, it will be so dirty.

column2: Oh!	Oh!
That will not signify; I never mind dirt."
column3: That will not signify; I never mind dirt."

column2: No, replied her friend very placidly, "I know you never mind dirt."
column3: No, replied her friend very placidly, "I know you never mind dirt."

column2: So it does indeed.	So it does indeed.
If it keeps raining, the streets will be very wet."
column3: If it keeps raining, the streets will be very wet."

column2: There are four umbrellas up already.	There are four umbrellas up already.
I would much rather take a chair at any time."
column3: I would much rather take a chair at any time."

column2: It was such a nice-looking morning!	It was such a nice looking morning!
Anybody would have thought so indeed.	Anybody would have thought so indeed.

I hope Mr. Allen will put on his greatcoat when he goes, but I dare say he will not, for he had rather do anything in the world than walk out in a greatcoat; I wonder he should dislike it, it must be so comfortable."
column3: I hope mr Allen will put on his greatcoat when he goes, but I dare say he will not, for he had rather do anything in the world than walk out in a greatcoat; I wonder he should dislike it, it must be so comfortable."

column2: Catherine went every five minutes to the clock, threatening on each return that, if it still kept on raining another five minutes, she would give up the matter as hopeless.
column3: Catherine went every five minutes to the clock, threatening on each return that, if it still kept on raining another five minutes, she would give up the matter as hopeless.

column2: The clock struck twelve, and it still rained.
column3: The clock struck twelve, and it still rained.

column2: You will not be able to go, my dear.
column3: You will not be able to go, my dear.

column2: I do not quite despair yet.	I do not quite despair yet.
I shall not give it up till a quarter after twelve.
column3: I shall not give it up till a quarter after twelve.

column2: This is just the time of day for it to clear up, and I do think it looks a little lighter.
column3: This is just the time of day for it to clear up, and I do think it looks a little lighter.

column2: There, it is twenty minutes after twelve, and now I shall give it up entirely.
column3: There, it is twenty minutes after twelve, and now I shall give it up entirely.

column2: It was too dirty for Mrs. Allen to accompany her husband to the pump-room; he accordingly set off by himself, and Catherine had barely watched him down the street when her notice was claimed by the approach of the same two open carriages, containing the same three people that had surprised her so much a few mornings back.
column3: It was too dirty for mrs Allen to accompany her husband to the pump room; he accordingly set off by himself, and Catherine had barely watched him down the street when her notice was claimed by the approach of the same two open carriages, containing the same three people that had surprised her so much a few mornings back.

column2: Isabella, my brother, and Mr. Thorpe, I declare!	Isabella, my brother, and mr Thorpe, I declare!
They are coming for me perhaps--but I shall not go--I cannot go indeed, for you know Miss Tilney may still call." Mrs. Allen agreed to it.
column3: They are coming for me perhaps-but I shall not go-I cannot go indeed, for you know Miss Tilney may still call." mrs Allen agreed to it.

column2: John Thorpe was soon with them, and his voice was with them yet sooner, for on the stairs he was calling out to Miss Morland to be quick.

column2: Make haste!	Make haste!

But, however, I cannot go with you today, because I am engaged; I expect some friends every moment." This was of course vehemently talked down as no reason at all; Mrs. Allen was called on to second him, and the two others walked in, to give their assistance.

column2: My sweetest Catherine, is not this delightful?	My sweetest Catherine, is not this delightful?

column2: I am in such ecstasies at the thoughts of a little country air and quiet!

column2: So much better than going to the Lower Rooms.

column2: I doubt our being able to do so much, said Morland.
column3: I doubt our being able to do so much, said Morland.

column2: You croaking fellow! cried Thorpe.

column2: We shall be able to do ten times more.	We shall be able to do ten times more.

column2: Aye, and Blaize Castle too, and anything else we can hear of; but here is your sister says she will not go."
column3: Aye, and Blaize Castle too, and anything else we can hear of; but here is your sister says she will not go."

column2: Blaize Castle! cried Catherine.
column3: Blaize Castle! cried Catherine.

column2: What is that?
column3: What is that?

column2: The finest place in England--worth going fifty miles at any time to see.
column3: The finest place in England-worth going fifty miles at any time to see.

column2: What, is it really a castle, an old castle?
column3: What, is it really a castle, an old castle?

column2: The oldest in the kingdom.
column3: The oldest in the kingdom.

column2: But is it like what one reads of?

column2: Not go!	Not go!
I cannot go, because--looking down as she spoke, fearful of Isabella's smile--"I expect Miss Tilney and her brother to call on me to take a country walk.
column3: I cannot go, because--looking down as she spoke, fearful of Isabella's smile-"I expect Miss Tilney and her brother to call on me to take a country walk.

column2: They promised to come at twelve, only it rained; but now, as it is so fine, I dare say they will be here soon."
column3: They promised to come at twelve, only it rained; but now, as it is so fine, I dare say they will be here soon."

column2: Not they indeed, cried Thorpe; "for, as we turned into Broad Street, I saw them--does he not drive a phaeton with bright chestnuts?"
column3: Not they indeed, cried Thorpe; "for, as we turned into Broad Street, I saw them-does he not drive a phaeton with bright chestnuts?"

column2: I do not know indeed.

column2: Did you indeed?

column2: But I suppose they thought it would be too dirty for a walk."
column3: But I suppose they thought it would be too dirty for a walk."

It has not been so dirty the whole winter; it is ankle-deep everywhere."

column2: Isabella corroborated it: "My dearest Catherine, you cannot form an idea of the dirt; come, you must go; you cannot refuse going now."

column2: Yes, yes, every hole and corner.

column2: She could not think the Tilneys had acted quite well by her, in so readily giving up their engagement, without sending her any message of excuse.
column3: She could not think the Tilneys had acted quite well by her, in so readily giving up their engagement, without sending her any message of excuse.

column2: It was now but an hour later than the time fixed on for the beginning of their walk; and, in spite of what she had heard of the prodigious accumulation of dirt in the course of that hour, she could not from her own observation help thinking that they might have gone with very little inconvenience.

column2: On the other hand, the delight of exploring an edifice like Udolpho, as her fancy represented Blaize Castle to be, was such a counterpoise of good as might console her for almost anything.
column3: On the other hand, the delight of exploring an edifice like Udolpho, as her fancy represented Blaize Castle to be, was such a counterpoise of good as might console her for almost anything.

column2: They passed briskly down Pulteney Street, and through Laura Place, without the exchange of many words.
column3: They passed briskly down Pulteney Street, and through Laura Place, without the exchange of many words.

column2: Thorpe talked to his horse, and she meditated, by turns, on broken promises and broken arches, phaetons and false hangings, Tilneys and trap-doors.
column3: Thorpe talked to his horse, and she meditated, by turns, on broken promises and broken arches, phaetons and false hangings, Tilneys and trap doors.

column2: As they entered Argyle Buildings, however, she was roused by this address from her companion, "Who is that girl who looked at you so hard as she went by?"

column2: On the right-hand pavement--she must be almost out of sight now. Catherine looked round and saw Miss Tilney leaning on her brother's arm, walking slowly down the street.

column2: I must go back to Miss Tilney." But Mr. Thorpe only laughed, smacked his whip, encouraged his horse, made odd noises, and drove on; and Catherine, angry and vexed as she was, having no power of getting away, was obliged to give up the point and submit. Her reproaches, however, were not spared.

column2: How could you say that you saw them driving up the Lansdown Road?

column2: I would not have had it happen so for the world.

column2: They must think it so strange, so rude of me!
